answers.author: Derek Johnson
answers.text:
Candace,   
Retaining institutional knowledge is a challenge for both public and private organizations. Many businesses and local governments are exploring concrete steps and philosophies for passing on the most valuable knowledge of their most experienced workers to the next generation:   
http://icma.org/en/Article/11369/Succession_Planning__The_Essentials 
Here is a detailed report from Patrick Ibarra of The Mejorando Group. Relevant findings include:   
Eight features that any reliable succession plan must have   
 The unique and challenge to institutional memory posed by the looming baby boomer retirement crisis   
-Best practices for developing a coherent succession plan   
http://icma.org/en/ca/activities_and_programs/coaching/succession_planning 
Also, see what our Cal-ICMA Affiliate and the City of San Bernardino has to say on the subject of succession plans. Click on the link, then open the Microsoft Word document "San Bernardino Management Succession Plan" to read about a multi-step process for fostering the next generation of future leadership to step in after the prior generation has stepped down.   
Hope this helps!

answers.author: Jennifer Behrens
answers.text:
I work for a local government department, which recently organized a Knowledge Management System using an interactive intra-net system.  Information is recognized as formal or tacit (informal) knowledge.  Formal knowledge is captured through narratives and flow charts for all identified key processes throughout the organization.  Tacit knowledge is captured through brief narratives that provide tips or work-arounds not typically found in traditional policy or protocol (the daily "know-how.") The KMS processes are used in teaching incoming, new staff and also as cross-agency learning mechanisms. Please let me know if you would like to discuss further or if I can clarify anything (jbehrens@albemarle.org).

author: Candace Talmadge
text: I am helping to write an article for Public Management on the topic of knowledge transfer between the generation of leaders and managers who are retiring and the generation of leaders and managers who follow them. What are some of the challenges public sector organizations face in passing along what they know to their successors? Has anyone found a consistent way to handle this issue? I hope to do phone interviews during October. Thanks.
title: Knowledge transfer
